_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility has developed a risk management program to address Requirements for the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP).( 40 CFR Part 68 - "Risk Management Programs (RMP) for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention". (EPA)) The facility is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facility's staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia for NOx Reduction. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES



Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Selective Catalytic Reduction System.  Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility utilizes ammonia for their Selective Catalytic Reduction System to control nitrous oxide emissions.  Two Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Tanks, each with a 30,000 gallon capacity and 85% maximum fill by administrative controls, are kept at the facility.      



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined for the process.  The results can be found in the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab located in the RMP Compliance Workbook.



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: A realistic alternative release scenario was defined for the process.  The results can be found in the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab located in the RMP Compliance Workbook.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential r

isks; Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and facility personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

?    There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.

?    The system undergoes scheduled maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

?    Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by facility personnel, as necessary.

The history of Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility (i.e., no RMP -applicable ammonia releases in the last five years) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Selective Catalytic Reduction System.

its (CA)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at the facility in at least the past five years.  



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE 

The use of flammable materials at Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



EMERGENCY PLANNING & RESPONSE 

CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency. Calpine - Pastoria Energy Facility has an Emergency Action Plan, which can be found in Attachment A of the EMERGENCY PLANNING & RESPONSE Tab and this plan includes:

?    Emergency Alarm Procedures

?    Evacuation Procedures

?    Safety and Health Considerations

?    Notification Procedures

Although the plant is listed in Section 9.1.a. 'as a facility NOT included in the written community emergency response plan', they may, however, assist in an emergency. The Facility's written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) involves coordination with local emergency responders and compliance with emergency response planning is conducted, coordinated and submitted through the California Environmental Reporting System (CERS).



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility is extremely diligent in the handling of anhydrous ammonia. Planned changes to improve safety and the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program are listed in the Action Item Tracking Log as recommendations in APPENDIX A.
